Amazon.com plans to more than double its annual base pay cap to US$350,000 (HK$2.72 million) from its previous maximum salary of US$160,000 for US employees.

The e-commerce giant will also increase the overall compensation range for most jobs globally, and the company said in a memo that the increases were much more "considerable" than in the past.

"This past year has seen a particularly competitive labor market," the memo stated. It added there was a "need to remain competitive for attracting and retaining top talent."

Amazon last year increased its average starting pay for operations staff in the United States to more than US$18 an hour against the backdrop of a tight labor market. The company will also review compensation for newly promoted employees at the time they go up in the world and give in-year stock awards, if required, to put them into the new pay range.
